metadata.title: The First Wave of COVID-19 in Israel -Initial Analysis of Publicly Available Data

body_text.text: The first case of COVID-19 was confirmed in Israel on February 21, 2020. On March 9, 2 a two-week self-isolation was imposed on all people coming from abroad and on March 3 12, schools and universities were closed by the government order, partially switching to 4 distant teaching. Then, on March 19, when the number of daily confirmed cases 5 exceeded 100, all non-essential businesses were ordered to close, the employees were 6 required to increase social distancing of their workers and, if possible, allow them to 7 work from home, whereas people's movement outside their homes was restricted 8 significantly. Still, by March 23, the number of confirmed cases climbed up to 1, 000, 9 accompanied by a doubling period of less than 3 days. A continuous decrease in the 10 growth rate has started only around March 29, after the total number of confirmed 11 cases exceeded 4, 000. By April 30, the doubling period went up to several weeks with 12 only 222 death outcomes out of 15, 946 confirmed cases. 13 Sweden, a country slightly more populated than Israel, detected its first COVID-19 14 cases around February 26. The evolution of the epidemic in both countries is compared 15 in Fig 1. Initially, the total number of confirmed cases grew up much faster in Sweden 16 than in Israel, exceeding 1, 000 on March 15. However, despite much softer intervention 17 policy in Sweden than in Israel, both countries kept reporting similar amounts of seemed to have a limited effect on their reported infection rate. On the other hand, 22 Sweden is suffering a much higher mortality rate than Israel, with the current ratio of 23 about 10 : 1 between the amount of death outcomes in the two countries. With the peak unemployment rate of 24%, mostly due to people placed on unpaid 25 leave as a result of the pandemic, the Israeli government decided to partially lift the 26 lockdown, which has been maintained throughout the Passover holiday (April 7-16). 27 The "exit strategy" steps under consideration included increasing the allowed 28 percentage of workers at workplaces, opening some shops, partially resuming public 29 transportation, gradually getting children back to school, and selectively releasing The subsequent sections will focus on each one of these crucial questions. Finally, we 47 will discuss the implications of our data analysis on the prospective decisions to be Following [5] , we assume that the COVID-19 outbreak can be represented by SIR 67 dynamics, which assumes that at any given point of time, each individual in the 68 population belongs to one of the following three states: (I)nfected, (S)usceptible to 69 infection, or (R)emoved from the transmission process. However, the original SIR model 70 and its variations, like SEIR (susceptible-exposed-infected-recovered) [4] , are 71 continuous time models based on a set of differential equations. In contrast, we 72 represent the COVID-19 dynamics by a discrete time model, which is more appropriate 73 for the time series data of daily case counts. Fixing the total size of the population 74 under a discrete time SIR model implies that the sum of the daily changes in the 75 amount of individuals belonging to each one of the above three compartments should be 76 equal to zero:

where I t , S t , and R t stand for the changes in the total amount of infected, susceptible, 78 and recovered people, respectively, between the days t − 1 and t. Our discrete time 79 model for the temporal evolution of the number of infected individuals builds upon the 80 basic reproduction number R 0 , which represents the average number of secondary 81 infections an infected person will cause before he or she is effectively removed from the 82 population as a result of recovery, hospitalization, quarantine, etc. [5] . As long as min T I and max T I represent, respectively, the minimum and the maximum number of 90 days from the start of the infectious period to the onset of the symptoms. We assume 91 that symptomatic individuals are not infectious anymore as they are immediately 92 isolated from the susceptible population and required to take a COVID-19 test. We also 93 assume that asymptomatic people are never referred to a test and that the social 94 behavior of infected individuals does not change during their infectious period. Hence,

body_text.text: As long as there is no daily testing of the entire population, the exact values of I t 120 remain unknown. However, in the next sub-section, we explain how one can estimate 121 the actual dynamics of infected cases from the currently available epidemiological data. 122
Estimating the Actual Infection Dynamics from Available Data 123

We assume that symptomatic individuals take a COVID-19 test on the day of the 124 symptoms onset (the end point of the incubation period), but it takes r days on average 125 to report a positive test result as a "confirmed case". Given the average incubation 126 period L I and the average reporting delay r, the time series of the daily number of new 127 infection cases I t is related to the time series of the daily number of confirmed cases C t 128 by Eq (4).

where p t is the reporting rate on day t, which is equal to 1 if there is a full and timely 130 detection of all positive cases, which requires daily testing of the entire population, and 131 greater than 1 when some under-reporting takes place.

While the amount of new confirmed COVID-19 cases in various countries, regions 133 and even cities is published on daily basis, its level of under-reporting is unknown and 134 potentially unstable due to inconsistent testing policy, varying reporting time, and other 135 factors and thus we cannot use it as a trustworthy indicator of the epidemic dynamics. 136 On the other hand, the daily number of virus-related deaths D t is expected to be much 137
May 5, 2020 4/12 . CC-BY-ND 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 8, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.05.05.20091645 doi: medRxiv preprint more reliable than the testing results and it should not suffer from any significant 138 reporting delay. Assuming a fixed Infection Fatality Rate IF R, we can estimate the 139 daily amount of infection cases on day t as a function of the amount of death outcomes 140 on day t + L I + d, where d is the average number of days between the onset of the virus 141 symptoms and the patient death (see Eq 5) . Hence, disregarding the true value of IF R, 142 we can explore the dynamics of the daily death rate D t as a time-shifted substitute for 143 the true infection rate IR t (Eq 6). Given the average reporting delay r, we can also 144 estimate the Case Fatality Rate (CFR), which is defined in epidemiology as the 145 proportion of people who die from a specified disease among all individuals diagnosed 146 with the disease over a certain period of time [6] . Since the CFR numerator is restricted 147 to deaths among people included in the denominator, we calculate it as the average 148 ratio between the amount of death outcomes on day t + d − r and the number of 149 confirmed cases on day t (Eq 7).

body_text.text: The Epidemic Dynamics in Israel and Sweden

Our analysis of COVID-19 evolution in Israel is based on the following timing 153 parameters provided in [8, 9] : is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 8, 2020. . the mean generation interval. The chart also shows the main intervention measures 173 taken by the Israeli government during the same period. Since we did not have enough 174 data to estimate the infection rate before March 25, we could not evaluate the direct 175 effect of the school closing around March 12 as well as business activity and movement 176 restrictions imposed on March 19. 177 Apparently, the emergency regulations declared on March 25, which forced most 178 Israelis to stay at their homes, have contributed to social distancing by quickly reducing 179 the mean value of R 0 from 1.26 to 1.00 within 5 days only. An additional decrease in 180 R 0 observed in the beginning of April could be caused by more people wearing masks in 181 public. The Passover lockdown is the most likely factor that brought the reproduction 182 number below 0.70 by April 15, which was the last official day of the Holiday. As can be 183 seen on the same chart, after R 0 went below the value of 1.0, the doubling rate (number 184 of days required to double the number of infected people) climbed highly above the 10 185 days threshold, which was defined in the Government decision from May 04, 2020 as one 186 of the criteria for rolling back the "exit strategy" steps. The true Infection Rate (IR) of COVID-19, like any other epidemic, is a 200 non-decreasing function of time. Hopefully, it will be measured in the near future using 201 massive serological tests but its true past values will remain unknown forever. However, 202 we believe, like the authors of [10] , that the Test Positivity Rate (TPR), the fraction of 203 positive to total tests, should be an upper bound on the IR during the first few weeks of 204 infection. Fig 4 shows the 7 -day moving averages for TPR and for the daily amount of 205 tests between March 11 and April 25. Since the mean TPR reached its peak value of 206 May 5, 2020 6/12 . We also have no plausible explanation for the exceptionally low 222 CFR values in Israel compared to Sweden and to the world average of 3.6% in general. 223 The reasons for the significant gaps between mortality rates in different countries and 224 regions deserve a separate study as they may include differences in lab testing strategies, 225 clinical treatment practices, outcome classification policies, coronavirus strains, etc. parameters: maximum required number of respirators, total amount of death outcomes, 233 and the extent of herd immunity at the end of the simulated period. Following [9] , we 234 assume that the average stay on respirator is equal to 10 days and that the average 235 May 5, 2020 8/12 . body_text.text: • R0 = 1.05. This value may be slightly easier to implement in terms of social 269 distancing than R 0 = 1.0, but it will cause a steady, though a slow growth in the 270 daily infection rate up to 2, 500 cases per day by the end of November. This means 271 Israel will need about 600 respirators at that time. According to this scenario, at 272 least 4% of Israeli population will become immune to COVID-19 by the end of 273 November, but the total number of death outcomes in Israel may approach 5, 000. 274

• R0 = 1.10. This more severe scenario will increase the daily infection rate up to 275 9, 500 cases in mid-October before starting a decrease down to 8, 000 by the end of 276 November due to an increasing percentage of population immunity. At its peak, it 277 will require more than 2, 000 respirators. About 16, 000 people are expected to die 278 from the virus during the simulated period, with at least 12% of the population 279 getting immunity.

• R0 = 1.20. This is the most extreme and hopefully the least realistic scenario we 281 have considered. Its peak is expected in August, when we may expect about 282 33, 000 new cases per day requiring as many as 7, 500 respirators, well above the 283 current capacity of the Israeli hospitals. However, by the end of November, the 284 May 5, 2020 9/12 . CC-BY-ND 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 8, 2020. . daily infection rate should go down to less than 1, 000, due to at least one-third of 285 the population becoming immune to the virus. This radical scenario may result in 286 a death toll of about 40, 000 people. The future evolution of COVID-19 in Israel and elsewhere is hardly predictable. Until a 289 vaccine becomes available, which may take many months from now, the governments 290 will have to strike the tough balance between health and economic issues. Obviously, 291 the implementation of the "exit strategy" by the Israeli Government will require a close 292 monitoring of the reproduction number. It is unclear at this stage how long R 0 can be 293 kept below the value of 0.80, which apparently is needed for meeting the current "exit 294 strategy" criteria. To ensure the country's return to a proper level of economic activity, 295 it may be necessary to tolerate higher values of R 0 up to 1.0 and even 1.05, and we 296 May 5, 2020 10/12 . body_text.text: The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 8, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.05.05.20091645 doi: medRxiv preprint would strongly suggest the Israeli Ministry of Health to make the necessary preparations 297 for such a scenario. However, a further increase in R 0 beyond the value of 1.05 should 298 certainly be avoided by temporarily restoring the lockdown measures.
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: A further progress in understanding the current pandemic will be possible with a 300 release of detailed clinical records of COVID-19 patients in Israel and other countries to 301 the research community. Analyzing these records with state-of-the-art statistical and 302 machine learning algorithms may reveal answers to many important epidemiological 303 questions such as an accurate and early detection of high-risk patients, identification of 304 the most infectious persons and locations, characterization of the most common 305 infection pathways, etc. Many thousands of human lives worldwide are at risk and, as 306 we all know, "data saves lives".

At the time of a 84 pandemic, the value of R 0 may be reduced by decreasing the amount of social 85 interaction (a measure known as "social distancing"). Additional parameters used by 86 our model include the average duration of the incubation period L I between the 87 exposure and the onset of clinical symptoms and the generation time 88 [L I − max T I ; L I − min T I ] between the primary case and the secondary case, where89

FIGREF5.text: values I i , the incubation period L I , the generation time range 98 [L I − max T I ; L I − min T I ], and the population size N , we can use a stochastic 99 optimization method to find the value of R 0 , which should reconstruct that series with 100 a minimal average absolute error. The error can be further reduced by splitting the 101 time series into several segments and estimating R 0 for each segment separately. 102 To monitor the evolution of R 0 on daily basis, we can take several simplifying 103 assumptions. First, we assume that as long as only a small proportion of a country's 104 population is infected, the number of susceptible individuals S t remains close to the 105 total population size N . We also assume the generation time to be fixed to the 106 midpoint day of the interval [L I − max T I ; L I − min T I ].

FIGREF6.text: is a linear autoregressive process of order L I − (min T I + max T I )/2 + 1 and 109 thus we can use the least squares method to estimate the value of R 0 from the daily 110 counts of new infected cases. Since R 0 may be affected by multiple factors, such as the 111 level of social distancing, we can monitor its change over time by calculating the moving 112 slope of the autoregression equation (3) over a sliding window of n days. 113 To project the epidemic dynamics into the future, we just need to choose the 114 expected value of R 0 , initialize the daily amounts of infected people on the last L I days 115 before the beginning of the projection period, and start calculating the succeeding 116 values of I t recursively using Eq (2). A similar simulation paradigm was implemented 117 in [7] to evaluate several transmission and intervention scenarios for COVID-19 in the 118

FIGREF8.text: COVID-19 Dynamics in Israel. March 25 -April 15, 2020 Fig 3 shows the 14-day moving average of R 0 in Sweden from March 15 to April 15, 188 2020. The daily number of infection cases was calculated using the estimated Infection 189 Fatality Ratio (IFR) of 14.82%. The chart also shows the main intervention measures 190 taken by the Swedish government during the same period. On March 24, the mean 191 reproduction number in Sweden reached its peak value of 1.33, just slightly higher than 192 R 0 observed at that time in Israel (1.26). Following the restrictions on various 193 recreation activities, it went down sharply to 0.58 within just four days. It is noteworthy 194 that in Israel, much stricter restrictions reduced R 0 to 1.0 only. After March 28, the 195 Swedish reproduction number fluctuated between 0.6 and 0.8, eventually converging to 196 0.56, a lower value than in Israel during the same period (0.68). While it is evident that 197 Sweden did a better job than Israel in terms of social distancing, the effect of various 198 measures on the actual public behavior in each country requires further investigation.

Source: https://data.gov.il/dataset/covid-19 Figs 5 and 6 show the calculation of the Case Fatality Ratio (CFR) in Israel and 212 Sweden, respectively, as a slope of a linear regression model between the cumulative 213 amount of confirmed cases and the cumulative number of death outcomes 7 days later. 214 The line equations, with the intercept set to 0, are y = 0.0146x for Israel and 215 y = 0.1502x for Sweden, which implies an order of magnitude difference between the 216 CFR of the two countries (1.46% vs 15%). The high values of R-Square (0.98) in both 217 regression models may indicate that most COVID-19 deaths are related to previously 218 confirmed cases. This result supports the hypothesis that most symptomatic patients 219 are detected by the lab tests and thus the actual Infection Rate should be close to its 220 lower bound. However, we do not have and may never have enough data to test this

Lag: 7 days Projecting into the Future 227 Based on the infection data estimated up to April 15, Figs 7 and 8 simulate the 228 projected number of daily and cumulative infection cases, respectively, for various 229 possible values of the reproduction number R0. Our simulation covers the period from 230 the beginning of May to the end of November, when we may be close to a start of a new 231 flu season in Israel. These projected numbers allow us to forecast three important232

FIGREF13.text: of required respirators should be equal to 23% of the maximum 237 number of daily infections. The number of respirators used by COVID-19 patients 238 (70 − −80) in the beginning of May 2020 is very close to the above estimator based on 239 the moving average of new infections started about two weeks earlier. The projected 240 extent of population immunity is calculated as a ratio between the cumulative number 241 of projected infections and the size of the Israeli population (8.9 million), under a 242 conservative assumption that the current Case Fatality Ratio of 1.46% is close to the 243 actual Infection Ratio (IR). The total number of death outcomes can be estimated as a 244 product of the currently known Case Fatality Ratio (1.46%) by the cumulative number 245 of infections. 246 Here is a brief discussion of each simulated scenario: 247 • R0 = 0.60. Based on the recent dynamics, where R 0 stayed between 0.6 and 0.7 248 at the time of a massive lockdown, this value may imply a continuous slowdown of 249 the Israeli economy. However, it is expected to eliminate the local epidemic by the 250 beginning of June at a minimal cost of about 30 additional death outcomes. On 251 the other hand, a vast majority of Israeli population will remain susceptible to the 252 virus, even if the current Infection Rate in Israel is close to its testing-based upper 253 bound of 10%. It is noteworthy that the daily amounts of new cases reported in 254 the beginning of May are very close to the numbers predicted using this value of 255 R 0 . R0 = 0.80. This value was observed in Israel after significant economic restrictions 257 but before the Passover lockdown. If the corresponding amount of social 258 distancing can be maintained by the entire population, the local virus cases should 259 be eliminated by the beginning of August, again without immunity for at least 260 90% of people. At these and lower values of R 0 , the Government criterion of less 261 than 100 new daily cases from an unknown source should be met most of the time. 262 • R0 = 1.00. This value seems to be achievable with minimal economic restrictions. 263 Rather than eliminating the virus, it will keep the daily infection rate at 200 to 264 300 cases (exceeding the Government criterion of maximum 100 cases), resulting 265 in about 1, 000 additional deaths and at least 1% immunity by the end of 266 November. This scenario will require about 70 respirators on average, similar to 267 the number occupied in the beginning of May 2020.

What is the true Infection Rate (IR) in Israel, i.e. what is the actual fraction of infected people including those who were not tested for coronavirus during their What are the Case Fatality Rate (CFR) and the Infection Fatality Rate (IFR), defined as the ratio of COVID-19 attributed deaths to the number of confirmed cases and the total number of infection cases, respectively.

TABREF1.text: For daily case count data in Israel and other countries, we rely upon the Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) Cases Data, which is part of Humanitarian Data Exchange 53 (HDX) platform [1]. The data is compiled since 22 January 2020 by the Johns Hopkins 54 University Center for Systems Science and Engineering (JHU CCSE) from various sources such as the World Health Organization (WHO) and European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC). The available fields include Province/State, Country/Region, Last Update, Confirmed, Suspected, Recovered, and Deaths. The coronavirus testing data in Israel was downloaded from the COVID-19 Data Repository of the Israeli Ministry of Health [2] on April 28, 2020. The available fields included: test date, binary symptom indicators (cough, fever, sore throat, shortness of breath, head ache), corona result (positive, negative or other), binary age indicator (age 60 and above), gender, and test indication (Abroad, Contact with confirmed or Other). The data file contained the results of 313, 135 tests performed
